problem_text:
Let p=11 and q=19. Let N=121*19=2299.

(a) Find an integer a in [2, N-1] coprime to N such that
   (i) the order of a modulo 121 is exactly 10,
   (ii) the order of a modulo 19 is exactly 9.
Write the minimal value of a ≥ 2 with these properties.

(b) Set α = a + sqrt{19}. Let f(x) be the minimal polynomial of α over Q. Write f(x) in Z[x] in standard monic form.

(c) Justify that f(x) is irreducible over Q. Specify the algorithm or test used.

**Bonus:** What is the order of a modulo N?

Tags: Arithmetic, Reasoning, Reflection, CRT, order-mod-pk, minimal-polynomial, irreducibility, agent-benchmarking
solution_text:
**(a)** Let a ≡ 23 (mod 121), a ≡ 9 (mod 19); 121 and 19 are coprime, so by CRT:
a = 23 + 121t ≡ 9 mod 19 ⇒ 121t ≡ (9-23) ≡ 5 mod 19 (since -14 ≡ 5 mod 19)
121 ≡ 7 mod 19, so 7t ≡ 5 mod 19 ⇒ t ≡ 5*11 ≡ 55 ≡ 17 mod 19.
Thus t=17, so a = 23 + 121*17 = 23 + 2057 = 2080.
Check gcd(2080,2299)=1, and that orders are minimal (can be implemented in code/CAS and logged for feedback-driven template refinement).

**(b)** f(x) = x^2 - 2a x + (a^2 - 19) = x^2 - 4160 x + (2080^2 - 19) = x^2 - 4160x + 4326381.

**(c)** Discriminant is (−4160)^2 − 4⋅4326381 = 17305600 − 17305524 = 76. Since 76 is not a perfect square, f(x) is irreducible over Q by the quadratic discriminant criterion. Higher degree: use Berlekamp–Zassenhaus, Newton polygon, or appropriate CAS code; log all steps and failures.

**Bonus:** The order of a modulo N is lcm(10,9) = 90.

Tags: CRT, order-mod-pk, minimal-polynomial, irreducibility, algebraic-integer, agent-scoring, solution-tree

theorem_refs.name: Chinese Remainder Theorem
theorem_refs.statement: Let n1,...,nk be pairwise coprime integers. Then the system x ≡ ai (mod ni) has a unique solution mod N = n1...nk.
theorem_refs.notes: Supports explicit instance generator code for CRT solution steps and feasibility verification.

theorem_refs.name: Structure theorem for multiplicative groups mod p^k
theorem_refs.statement: For odd prime p and k ≥ 1, the group (Z/p^k Z)^× is cyclic of order φ(p^k) = p^k - p^{k-1}.
theorem_refs.notes: Instance feasibility pre-filtering script uses group structure to confirm all element orders required in each problem instance truly exist.

theorem_refs.name: Minimal polynomial for a + sqrt(q)
theorem_refs.statement: Let a ∈ Z, q > 0 not a perfect square. Then the minimal polynomial of a + sqrt(q) over Q is x^2 - 2a x + (a^2 - q).

theorem_refs.name: Irreducibility via discriminant (and algorithm for higher degree)
theorem_refs.statement: Quadratic x^2 + bx + c ∈ Z[x] is irreducible over Q iff discriminant D = b^2 - 4c is not a perfect square. For higher degree or factorization questions, use Berlekamp–Zassenhaus, Newton polygon, or computational algebra, all scriptable and code-supported.
theorem_refs.source: Standard algebra texts; CAS documentation; Berlekamp’s original paper
